question: Is the following goal a behavioral goal or an outcome goal? 'I will lose 10 pounds in two months.'

options.A: Behavioral goal
options.B: Outcome goal
options.C: Both
options.D: Neither

explanations.A: Behavioral goals focus on specific actions (e.g., walking 30 mins daily), not outcomes. (NBHWC 2.4, *Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 133)
explanations.B: Correct. This is an outcome goal because it describes a result, not a behavior. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 85)
explanations.C: This is not both—a goal is either behavior-focused or outcome-focused. This one is clearly outcome-based.
explanations.D: Incorrect. This fits the standard definition of an outcome goal. (*Health & Wellness Coaching*, Ch. 5)

question: A client in your coaching session begins asking for specific advice on supplements and mentions a recent lab test. What is the most appropriate action for a health and wellness coach to take?

options.A: Recommend evidence-based supplements to address nutrient gaps
options.B: Refer the client to a licensed healthcare professional
options.C: Interpret the lab results to help the client take informed action
options.D: Share anecdotal experiences with similar issues

explanations.A: Outside scope—coaches cannot prescribe or recommend supplements unless licensed. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Correct. Referral is appropriate when clinical interpretation is needed. (NBHWC 1.2, Code of Ethics)
explanations.C: Interpreting labs is a clinical task and not within the coach’s role. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, Ch. 10)
explanations.D: Sharing personal stories may bias the session and shifts focus from client autonomy. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: Which of the following is true about brainstorming sessions?

options.A: Brainstorming sessions last as long as they need to.
options.B: Very specific answers.
options.C: No evaluation of quality of answers
options.D: All of the above

explanations.A: While brainstorming is flexible, session timing alone doesn’t define its nature. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.B: Incorrect. Brainstorming encourages broad, creative thinking—not specific answers. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 123)
explanations.C: Correct. Evaluating answers too soon limits creativity and client ownership. (NBHWC 2.3)
explanations.D: Not all listed options are correct—only C accurately describes the coaching use of brainstorming.

question: Which of the following behaviors demonstrates active listening?

options.A: Interrupting to clarify the client's points
options.B: Nodding and summarizing what the client said
options.C: Taking notes without making eye contact
options.D: Thinking about the next question to ask

explanations.A: Interrupting disrupts the client’s flow and does not reflect true listening. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 74)
explanations.B: Correct. Active listening involves nonverbal engagement and reflective summarizing. (NBHWC 2.2, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Note-taking without engagement can signal disinterest and disconnect. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.D: Focusing on what to say next reduces attentiveness to the client’s words. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: A client says, “I know I should be more active, but I just hate going to the gym.” What is the best coaching response?

options.A: Why don’t you like going to the gym?
options.B: Let’s explore why being active matters to you.
options.C: Maybe you could try a different gym.
options.D: Try to go just twice a week for now.

explanations.A: ‘Why’ questions can sound critical and may reduce trust. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 65)
explanations.B: Correct. This response explores internal motivation and meaning, which supports autonomy. (NBHWC 2.4, *MI*)
explanations.C: Offering suggestions without evoking the client’s ideas may reduce empowerment. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Prescriptive advice early in the conversation may lead to resistance. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: Which of the following is true about the Transtheoretical Model?

options.A: It includes five stages of change
options.B: It’s only relevant for addiction coaching
options.C: It encourages coaches to offer advice in all stages
options.D: It assumes clients are always ready to act

explanations.A: Correct. The model includes Precontemplation, Contemplation, Preparation, Action, and Maintenance. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 23)
explanations.B: The model applies broadly to health behavior change, not just addiction. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.C: Coaching emphasizes evoking rather than advising, especially in early stages. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Clients often move back and forth through stages; readiness is not assumed. (*Changing to Thrive*)

question: What is the best reflection for a client who says, “I want to change my diet, but I love fast food”?

options.A: So you're not serious about eating healthy?
options.B: You’re torn between wanting to eat better and enjoying fast food.
options.C: Maybe you can eat fast food only on weekends.
options.D: You should cut out fast food completely.

explanations.A: Judgmental reflections can harm rapport and shut down dialogue. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. This is a double-sided reflection that supports ambivalence resolution. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 150)
explanations.C: Premature advice may reduce client engagement. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Directive language contradicts client-centered coaching. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: In Motivational Interviewing, which of the following is a core skill?

options.A: Diagnosing resistance
options.B: Arguing for change
options.C: Using affirmations
options.D: Correcting misinformation

explanations.A: MI avoids pathologizing behavior and instead focuses on understanding resistance. (*MI*, Miller & Rollnick)
explanations.B: Arguing for change increases resistance and reduces collaboration. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 25)
explanations.C: Correct. Affirmations build client confidence and self-efficacy. (NBHWC 2.2, *MI*, p. 93)
explanations.D: Correcting can be helpful, but only with permission and timing—it’s not a core skill. (NBHWC 1.1)

question: Which of the following goals is SMART?

options.A: I want to be healthy someday
options.B: I will eat 3 servings of vegetables per day for the next 4 weeks
options.C: I’ll probably start walking more soon
options.D: Lose weight fast

explanations.A: This is vague and lacks time or measurement. (NBHWC 2.4, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Correct. This goal is Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.C: ‘Probably’ indicates low commitment and lack of clarity. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.D: ‘Fast’ is subjective and not a measurable metric. (NBHWC 2.4)

question: Which of the following is an appropriate coach action when a client identifies a desire to reduce stress?

options.A: Immediately recommend meditation
options.B: Ask what they’ve tried so far and what’s worked
options.C: Explain how stress affects cortisol
options.D: Refer them to therapy

explanations.A: Offering solutions too early may reduce engagement. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Correct. Exploring past success supports empowerment and resource activation. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.C: While educational, this shifts focus away from client experience. (NBHWC 1.1)
explanations.D: Referral is only needed if the client exhibits signs beyond coaching scope. (NBHWC Scope)

question: Which of the following is an example of affirming a client during a coaching session?

options.A: You've clearly thought this through and taken big steps forward.
options.B: Why didn't you try a different strategy sooner?
options.C: Let's go over what didn't work last time.
options.D: You've been struggling with this for a while now.

explanations.A: Correct. This affirmation recognizes the client's effort and supports self-efficacy. (*MI*, p. 93; NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.B: This is critical and may damage rapport rather than build confidence. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.C: Focusing on past failures can lower motivation unless reframed constructively. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: This statement may reinforce struggle instead of celebrating strengths. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: A client says they are thinking about changing but are not ready to act. Which stage of change are they in?

options.A: Precontemplation
options.B: Contemplation
options.C: Preparation
options.D: Action

explanations.A: Precontemplation involves no recognition of the need for change. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 31)
explanations.B: Correct. Contemplation involves ambivalence and awareness without commitment. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.C: Preparation includes intention and small steps toward change. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Action refers to active behavior change, not just consideration. (*Changing to Thrive*)

question: Which of the following statements best reflects the coaching mindset?

options.A: I will educate my clients on the right lifestyle choices.
options.B: Clients need accountability to stick to plans.
options.C: Clients are naturally resourceful and capable of change.
options.D: I need to motivate my clients to change.

explanations.A: This puts the coach in an expert role rather than collaborative partner. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Accountability is important, but should be client-led, not imposed. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Correct. A core coaching belief is that clients are whole and resourceful. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 16)
explanations.D: Motivation is evoked, not instilled by the coach. (*MI*, p. 20)

question: What is the role of the coach during the Preparation stage of change?

options.A: Explore ambivalence about change
options.B: Evoke values and vision
options.C: Support goal setting and small actions
options.D: Identify barriers to change

explanations.A: This is more relevant in the Contemplation stage. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 58)
explanations.B: Visioning often occurs earlier to build readiness. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.C: Correct. In Preparation, the client is ready to plan and take small steps. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 72)
explanations.D: Barriers are addressed throughout, but action is central in Preparation. (NBHWC Goal Setting)

question: Which coaching technique is most appropriate when a client is feeling discouraged?

options.A: Point out what they did wrong
options.B: Remind them of their commitment
options.C: Explore past successes and strengths
options.D: Suggest a stronger plan

explanations.A: Focusing on failure can increase discouragement. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.B: This may feel like pressure rather than support. (*MI*, p. 61)
explanations.C: Correct. Exploring strengths supports confidence and intrinsic motivation. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 104)
explanations.D: This assumes the coach knows best, rather than empowering the client. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: Which of the following best describes a 'powerful question'?

options.A: A question that pushes the client to take action
options.B: A question that leads to a yes or no answer
options.C: A question that invites reflection and insight
options.D: A question that helps diagnose the client’s issue

explanations.A: Coaching avoids pushing; it invites discovery. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: Yes/no questions limit exploration and insight. (*MI*, p. 74)
explanations.C: Correct. Powerful questions evoke values, insight, and self-awareness. (NBHWC 2.2, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Diagnosing is outside the coaching scope. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)

question: Which of the following best reflects the use of reflective listening?

options.A: Offering a similar personal story
options.B: Repeating the client’s words verbatim
options.C: Summarizing what you heard to check understanding
options.D: Telling the client what they should do

explanations.A: Sharing stories can shift focus away from the client. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.B: Repeating exactly is parroting, not reflection. (*MI*, p. 75)
explanations.C: Correct. Reflective listening includes paraphrasing and checking for meaning. (NBHWC 2.2, *MI*)
explanations.D: Advising undermines autonomy and self-directed learning. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: What is the most coach-like response to a client saying: “I’ve failed at every diet I’ve tried.”?

options.A: Why do you think that is?
options.B: Maybe you haven’t tried hard enough.
options.C: It sounds like you’ve had some frustrating experiences.
options.D: You just need to stay focused this time.

explanations.A: ‘Why’ can sound judgmental and provoke defensiveness. (*MI*, p. 65)
explanations.B: Blaming the client breaks rapport and trust. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.C: Correct. This is an empathic reflection that validates the client’s feelings. (NBHWC 2.1, *MI*)
explanations.D: This advice may feel dismissive of the client’s lived experience. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: Which coaching approach is most appropriate for a client in the Action stage?

options.A: Help them identify long-term vision
options.B: Support problem-solving and sustaining change
options.C: Address ambivalence and explore values
options.D: Refer them to a mental health provider

explanations.A: Visioning is often used earlier to build motivation. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: Correct. Action stage involves taking steps and overcoming obstacles. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 87)
explanations.C: Ambivalence is usually resolved earlier (Contemplation/Preparation). (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.D: Referral is not required unless there’s a clinical need. (NBHWC Scope)

question: What is the most ethical coach response if a client begins discussing suicidal thoughts?

options.A: Listen deeply and keep the conversation confidential
options.B: Empathize and schedule more sessions to provide support
options.C: Immediately refer the client to appropriate mental health care
options.D: Help them make a plan to manage stress better

explanations.A: Safety overrides confidentiality in cases of harm risk. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Coaches are not trained to handle crises or suicidal ideation. (NBHWC Scope & Referral)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches must refer clients to qualified professionals in such situations. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.D: Offering support is not enough—this situation exceeds coaching scope. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, Ch. 10)

question: Which of the following is a key principle of Motivational Interviewing (MI)?

options.A: Correct the client's distorted beliefs
options.B: Confront the client’s resistance
options.C: Elicit the client’s own motivations for change
options.D: Offer logical reasons to change

explanations.A: MI avoids correcting and instead supports client autonomy. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 25)
explanations.B: MI works with, not against, resistance by rolling with it. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Correct. MI emphasizes evoking internal motivation for sustainable change. (*MI*, p. 18; NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Logic alone rarely results in lasting change without client engagement. (*MI*, p. 21)

question: Which of the following best illustrates a coach working within scope of practice?

options.A: Designing a personalized meal plan based on lab results
options.B: Diagnosing a client’s health condition from symptoms
options.C: Guiding a client to evidence-based nutrition resources
options.D: Suggesting herbal supplements for anxiety

explanations.A: This is a task for licensed dietitians or healthcare providers. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Diagnosis is explicitly outside the coaching role. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, Ch. 10)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches can guide clients to reputable resources to support self-directed change. (NBHWC 1.1)
explanations.D: Recommending supplements falls outside scope unless appropriately credentialed. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: A client has been consistently meeting their goals. What is the coach's most appropriate next step?

options.A: Ask how they might increase the difficulty
options.B: Celebrate their success and ask what they’ve learned
options.C: Move on to a different area of wellness
options.D: Advise them to maintain current behavior indefinitely

explanations.A: Increasing difficulty too quickly can backfire. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.B: Correct. Acknowledging wins and reflection fosters confidence and autonomy. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 104)
explanations.C: Shifting too soon may overlook valuable reflection and consolidation. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.D: Long-term advice assumes client readiness without their input. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: What is the coach’s role when a client expresses self-doubt?

options.A: Challenge their negative thinking
options.B: Reframe it with motivational statements
options.C: Invite the client to reflect on past strengths
options.D: Suggest they try harder

explanations.A: Challenging too directly can lead to defensiveness. (*MI*, p. 59)
explanations.B: Motivational statements from the coach may feel inauthentic. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Correct. Recalling strengths promotes empowerment and confidence. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 106)
explanations.D: Telling clients to try harder can reduce motivation. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: A client says, “I know I need to eat better, but I just don’t have time.” Which is the best coaching response?

options.A: Why don’t you make time for your health?
options.B: You sound overwhelmed—tell me more about what’s going on.
options.C: Here’s a quick plan you can follow.
options.D: You need to prioritize nutrition.

explanations.A: This can sound judgmental and shut down dialogue. (*MI*, p. 65)
explanations.B: Correct. This response shows empathy and invites client exploration. (NBHWC 2.2, *MI*)
explanations.C: Giving unsolicited plans removes ownership from the client. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Telling clients what they 'need' can reduce autonomy. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: Which of the following best reflects the concept of 'coach presence'?

options.A: Being prepared with educational materials
options.B: Being fully attentive and open in the moment
options.C: Having credentials and clinical knowledge
options.D: Having a clear coaching plan for each session

explanations.A: Being prepared is helpful but not the essence of presence. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.B: Correct. Presence is about mindful connection and attunement to the client. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 36)
explanations.C: Credentials are important but don’t define presence. (NBHWC 1.1)
explanations.D: A rigid plan may hinder flexibility and responsiveness. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: Which of the following is NOT a quality of effective goals?

options.A: Vague and exploratory
options.B: Time-bound
options.C: Specific
options.D: Measurable

explanations.A: Correct. Effective goals must be clear and actionable, not vague. (NBHWC 2.4, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Time-bound goals help with tracking and accountability. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 87)
explanations.C: Specific goals offer clarity and direction. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.D: Measurable goals allow progress to be evaluated. (*Health & Wellness Coaching*, Ch. 5)

question: When does a coach make a referral to another professional?

options.A: When the coach feels uncomfortable
options.B: When a client asks about legal advice
options.C: When a client wants faster results
options.D: When coaching strategies are ineffective

explanations.A: Referrals must be based on scope, not comfort alone. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Correct. Legal advice is outside coaching scope and requires referral. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.C: Wanting faster results doesn’t warrant referral if within coaching scope. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Ineffectiveness may call for adjustments—not automatically a referral. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which is an example of an open-ended question?

options.A: Did you walk today?
options.B: Have you tried journaling?
options.C: How do you feel after a walk?
options.D: Do you feel better now?

explanations.A: This is a yes/no question and limits exploration. (*MI*, p. 74)
explanations.B: Closed questions can be useful but don't invite deep reflection. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Correct. Open-ended questions explore experience and insight. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.D: This assumes improvement and restricts the client’s response. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which of the following best demonstrates empathy?

options.A: I understand what you're going through.
options.B: You're having a tough time right now.
options.C: You'll feel better soon.
options.D: It’s not that bad, others have it worse.

explanations.A: This may imply the coach knows how the client feels, which may not be true. (*MI*, p. 68)
explanations.B: Correct. This reflection acknowledges the client’s current emotional state. (NBHWC 2.1, *MI*)
explanations.C: This minimizes present emotions and assumes a future outcome. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.D: This dismisses and invalidates the client’s experience. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which of the following best represents a SMART goal?

options.A: I want to be healthier someday.
options.B: I plan to walk 30 minutes, 5 days a week, starting tomorrow.
options.C: I might try eating more vegetables soon.
options.D: I hope to lose some weight eventually.

explanations.A: Too vague and lacks specificity and timeframe. (NBHWC 2.4, SMART Goals)
explanations.B: Correct. This goal is Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 137)
explanations.C: Unclear and non-committal—doesn't meet SMART criteria. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.D: Lacks measurable and time-bound elements. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 86)

question: A client says, “I should really exercise more.” What’s the best coach response?

options.A: You know your body best. What has worked for you in the past?
options.B: Yes, you should—exercise is important.
options.C: Try this fitness app I use.
options.D: You need to start with a morning routine.

explanations.A: Correct. This respects autonomy and invites reflective thinking. (*MI*, p. 55; NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.B: Reinforces the 'righting reflex' and may provoke resistance. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.C: Unsolicited advice shifts focus away from client ownership. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Directive approach undermines client-driven discovery. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: Which of the following is within the NBHWC scope of practice?

options.A: Counseling a client through depression
options.B: Referring a client to a registered dietitian
options.C: Recommending supplements based on blood tests
options.D: Diagnosing chronic fatigue syndrome

explanations.A: Mental health counseling is outside scope unless licensed. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Correct. Coaches may refer to licensed professionals when needs exceed coaching boundaries. (NBHWC 1.1, 1.2)
explanations.C: Recommending supplements requires licensure and specific credentials. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Diagnosing is outside the health coach role. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: According to the CDC, what is the recommended amount of physical activity for adults per week?

options.A: 60 minutes of moderate-intensity activity
options.B: 150 minutes of moderate-intensity activity
options.C: 100 minutes of vigorous-intensity activity
options.D: 200 minutes of moderate activity

explanations.A: Too low—does not meet national guidelines. (CDC Physical Activity Guidelines)
explanations.B: Correct. The CDC recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise weekly. (CDC.gov)
explanations.C: Too little even at higher intensity unless supplemented. (CDC/AHA Guidelines)
explanations.D: 200 minutes is acceptable but not the minimum baseline. (ACSM/CDC)

question: What is the most appropriate way for a coach to handle a long silence during a session?

options.A: Quickly change the topic
options.B: Wait patiently and observe
options.C: Ask if the client is uncomfortable
options.D: Start summarizing the session

explanations.A: Changing the subject may interrupt client’s reflection. (NBHWC 2.1)
explanations.B: Correct. Silence often supports deeper thought and emotional processing. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 58)
explanations.C: May break the client’s internal process prematurely. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.D: Summarizing too early can disrupt the client’s direction. (NBHWC Ethics)

question: What is the coach’s best response if a client says, “I failed again. I’ll never change.”?

options.A: You need to be more disciplined.
options.B: That sounds hard—what feels most discouraging?
options.C: Let’s make a stricter plan for next time.
options.D: Maybe this isn’t the right goal for you.

explanations.A: Blaming reduces client confidence and violates empathy. (*MI*, p. 67)
explanations.B: Correct. This demonstrates empathic listening and opens space for reflection. (NBHWC 2.1, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Imposing structure too soon may overlook root emotion. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.D: May reinforce failure mindset instead of curiosity. (*MI*)

question: Which of the following best demonstrates the principle of autonomy?

options.A: Let me tell you what worked for other clients.
options.B: Here’s a proven method you should follow.
options.C: What approach feels right for you?
options.D: You’ll need to follow this schedule to succeed.

explanations.A: This shifts attention to others instead of empowering the client. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: Telling clients what to do minimizes their decision-making role. (*MI*, p. 18)
explanations.C: Correct. Supporting autonomy means helping clients choose their path. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.D: Over-prescriptive strategies violate client-centered coaching. (NBHWC Scope)

question: Which tool is most useful for supporting vision and goal alignment?

options.A: Health risk questionnaire
options.B: Food diary
options.C: Wellness vision statement
options.D: Referral form

explanations.A: This assesses risk but doesn’t engage intrinsic motivation. (NBHWC Assessment Tools)
explanations.B: Tracks eating habits but doesn’t reflect deeper goals. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. A wellness vision statement inspires and directs meaningful goal setting. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.D: Used for scope management, not vision alignment. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)

question: How should a coach respond if a client expresses interest in a restrictive fad diet?

options.A: Refer to a licensed dietitian for detailed advice
options.B: Tell them it’s unsafe and ineffective
options.C: Share your own dietary experiences
options.D: Recommend an alternative plan

explanations.A: Correct. Discussing restrictive diets is outside scope; refer to a qualified professional. (NBHWC Scope & Referral)
explanations.B: Labeling a client’s interest may create resistance. (*MI*, p. 64)
explanations.C: Self-disclosure can shift focus away from the client. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Offering plans is not within scope unless credentialed. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: A coach has a close friendship with a current client. What is the ethical response?

options.A: Maintain the friendship as long as sessions are separate
options.B: Pause coaching until the friendship resolves
options.C: Continue coaching if both parties agree
options.D: Refer the client to another coach

explanations.A: Dual relationships risk bias and conflict of interest. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Friendship conflicts with professional boundaries and objectivity. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Even mutual agreement doesn’t eliminate ethical concerns. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.D: Correct. Referring preserves professional boundaries and upholds ethical conduct. (NBHWC 1.2)

question: Which of the following best defines 'referral' in the coaching context?

options.A: Sending the client educational articles
options.B: Recommending a lifestyle app
options.C: Directing the client to a qualified professional for services outside your scope
options.D: Encouraging the client to self-research an issue

explanations.A: Sharing resources is educational but not a formal referral. (NBHWC 1.2)
explanations.B: App recommendations are tools, not referrals. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.C: Correct. A referral involves guiding a client to a licensed or qualified expert when appropriate. (NBHWC Ethics, Scope)
explanations.D: While promoting autonomy, self-research isn’t a professional referral. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which statement reflects a coach's use of positive psychology?

options.A: Let’s discuss your weaknesses first.
options.B: Tell me about a time you overcame a challenge.
options.C: We should focus on what went wrong.
options.D: You must avoid repeating past mistakes.

explanations.A: Focusing on deficits does not align with strengths-based coaching. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Correct. Recalling success builds self-efficacy and aligns with positive psychology principles. (NBHWC 2.3, *Positive Psychology Coaching*)
explanations.C: Negative focus can limit client empowerment. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Directive and problem-centered approaches may reduce client autonomy. (*MI*)

question: A coach notices a client showing signs of depression. What is the coach’s appropriate response?

options.A: Continue coaching while also exploring their feelings deeply
options.B: Diagnose the severity and suggest treatment
options.C: Pause coaching and offer counseling
options.D: Refer the client to a licensed mental health professional

explanations.A: Coaching should not attempt therapy or diagnose emotional conditions. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.B: Diagnosis is outside coaching scope. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Pausing is appropriate only if you are also a licensed provider, which is rare. (NBHWC Scope)
explanations.D: Correct. Coaches refer clients when mental health needs arise. (NBHWC 1.1, Code of Ethics)

question: Which of the following is true about brainstorming sessions?

options.A: Brainstorming sessions last as long as they need to.
options.B: Very specific answers are required.
options.C: No evaluation of quality of answers.
options.D: All of the above

explanations.A: Correct. Brainstorming promotes free, creative flow of ideas. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Correct. Specificity isn’t the goal—creativity is encouraged. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Correct. Judging ideas too early limits innovation. (NBHWC Goal Exploration)
explanations.D: Correct. All statements support the open, client-led nature of brainstorming. (*Appreciative Inquiry*)

question: A client consistently reschedules sessions and misses goals. What’s the best coach response?

options.A: Remind them of your cancellation policy
options.B: Explore what’s happening and revisit their readiness
options.C: Cancel the relationship due to lack of commitment
options.D: Continue without addressing the issue

explanations.A: While boundaries matter, it’s better to first explore the root issue. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.B: Correct. Exploring ambivalence can reveal obstacles and support autonomy. (*Changing to Thrive*, NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.C: Premature termination doesn’t serve client-centered practice. (*MI*, p. 72)
explanations.D: Avoiding the issue undermines the coaching relationship. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: What is the main focus of the Transtheoretical Model of Change?

options.A: Goal achievement through accountability
options.B: Skill development and confidence
options.C: Stages of readiness for change
options.D: Client education on behavior risks

explanations.A: Accountability is part of coaching but not the TTM’s core. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.B: Skill building matters, but TTM emphasizes readiness. (NBHWC 2.1)
explanations.C: Correct. TTM centers around five stages of change from precontemplation to maintenance. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 8)
explanations.D: Risk awareness may spark contemplation, but it’s not the model’s focus. (NBHWC Behavior Change)

question: Which best reflects the 'evoking' process in Motivational Interviewing?

options.A: Providing compelling facts about health risks
options.B: Encouraging the client to explore their own reasons to change
options.C: Correcting client assumptions gently
options.D: Telling the client how they might benefit

explanations.A: Providing facts can provoke resistance without internal motivation. (*MI*, p. 90)
explanations.B: Correct. Evoking draws out the client’s intrinsic motivations. (*MI*, p. 92; NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.C: Correcting assumptions is directive and not evoking. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Telling focuses on the coach’s ideas rather than the client’s voice. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: When should a coach re-contract or re-visit the coaching agreement?

options.A: Only at the beginning of a program
options.B: Any time the client’s goals or needs change
options.C: When the coach feels off-track
options.D: Only if the client requests it

explanations.A: Initial agreements set direction, but flexibility is needed. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. Contracts should adapt as goals evolve to support alignment. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 29)
explanations.C: Coach discomfort alone doesn’t justify re-contracting without client input. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Proactive revisiting supports accountability and trust. (NBHWC 1.1)

question: Which of the following questions best supports behavior change planning?

options.A: Why haven’t you made this change yet?
options.B: What’s one small step you feel ready to take?
options.C: Don’t you think this is important?
options.D: What’s stopping you from doing it now?

explanations.A: Focuses on past failure, not future movement. (*MI*, p. 112)
explanations.B: Correct. Promotes confidence, autonomy, and small wins. (NBHWC 2.4; *Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.C: Leads with judgment and reduces collaboration. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.D: Problem-focused questioning can feel confrontational. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: A client in the contemplation stage says, “I know I need to stop smoking, but I enjoy it.” What is the best coach response?

options.A: So, you’re not ready to change yet.
options.B: Quitting will be good for your health.
options.C: What are some things you enjoy about smoking and some things you don’t?
options.D: Let’s set a quit date now.

explanations.A: Labels can close off conversation. (*MI*, p. 47)
explanations.B: Telling reinforces external pressure, not exploration. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.C: Correct. This approach supports decisional balance and moves contemplation forward. (*MI*, *Changing to Thrive*, p. 82)
explanations.D: Premature action planning can ignore readiness. (NBHWC Stages of Change)
